column2: Poor thing! said the old poet, as he went to open the door.
column3: Poor thing! said the old poet, as he went to open the door.

column2: Poor child! said the old poet, as he took the boy by the hand.
column3: Poor child! said the old poet, as he took the boy by the hand.

column2: Thou shalt have wine and roasted apples, for thou art verily a charming child!" And the boy was so really.
column3: Thou shalt have wine and roasted apples, for thou art verily a charming child!" And the boy was so really.

column2: His eyes were like two bright stars; and although the water trickled down his hair, it waved in beautiful curls.
column3: His eyes were like two bright stars; and although the water trickled down his hair, it waved in beautiful curls.

column2: He looked exactly like a little angel, but he was so pale, and his whole body trembled with cold.
column3: He looked exactly like a little angel, but he was so pale, and his whole body trembled with cold.

column2: You are a merry fellow, said the old man.
column3: You are a merry fellow, said the old man.

column2: My name is Cupid, answered the boy.
column3: My name is Cupid, answered the boy.

column2: Don't you know me?	Don't you know me?
Look, the weather is now clearing up, and the moon is shining clear again through the window."
column3: Look, the weather is now clearing up, and the moon is shining clear again through the window."

column2: The poor poet lay on the earth and wept, for the arrow had really flown into his heart.
column3: The poor poet lay on the earth and wept, for the arrow had really flown into his heart.

column2: I will tell all children about him, that they may take care and not play with him, for he will only cause them sorrow and many a heartache."
column3: I will tell all children about him, that they may take care and not play with him, for he will only cause them sorrow and many a heartache."

column2: And all good children to whom he related this story, took great heed of this naughty Cupid; but he made fools of them still, for he is astonishingly cunning.
column3: And all good children to whom he related this story, took great heed of this naughty Cupid; but he made fools of them still, for he is astonishingly cunning.

column2: Yes, he is forever following people.
column3: Yes, he is forever following people.

column2: Ask them only and you will hear what they'll tell you.
column3: Ask them only and you will hear what they'll tell you.

column2: He is forever running after everybody.
column3: He is forever running after everybody.

column2: Only think, he shot an arrow once at your old grandmother!
column3: Only think, he shot an arrow once at your old grandmother!

column2: But that is a long time ago, and it is all past now; however, a thing of that sort she never forgets.
column3: But that is a long time ago, and it is all past now; however, a thing of that sort she never forgets.
